description:
I have been spending my days in GNU Emacs for a very long time now.  I've become habituated to its keybindings and it has become very hard for me to imagine using a computer without it.

Obviously I love Emacs, and I can recommend it to most of my fellow programmers, with some caveats: this one is an unusual "text editor" which requires some learning effort from your part, and you will spend a lot of time tweaking its settings to your liking and trying out new extensions and themes.  Depending on your approach, using Emacs could be fun and enjoyable, or just a nerdy computer thing you may want to avoid.
summary: Emacs is my primary text editor, plus a lot more

description: GNU Emacs is one of the most powerful and extensible tools that the Unix platforms has to offer. I can't really put it's usability in words, one has to experience it first hand to know it. But one thing I can say and that is, if you have free time and what it takes to learn this text-editor then go for it; it'll serve you for years to come, not just as a text-editor but also as a programming tool, a word processor, an IDE, anything you want it to be -- there's probably an emacs plugin for it.
